variant.question: Which of the following statements correctly summarises the basic functions of the Central Nervous System (CNS), Peripheral Nervous System (PNS) and the Autonomic Nervous System (ANS)?

options.text: The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord. The PNS provides the connection to the limbs and organs. The ANS governs the involuntary function of internal organs.
The CNS serves as the main processing unit. The PNS integrates the brain with the rest of the body. The ANS is responsible for muscle control of body movements.
The CNS connects the brain to the rest of the body. The PNS is responsible for the internal organs. The ANS governs the voluntary control of internal organs.
The CNS integrates all parts of the body. The PNS connects the brain via the spinal cord to all internal organs. The ANS is responsible for organ and muscle control.

variant.question: Name a beneficial effect of stress simulation in aviation.

options.text: Mastering unexpected situations in training makes pilots more confident in their ability to solve new problems and reduces the experienced stress level in actual situations.
Flight instructors can detect such pilots who are unable to perform adequately under pressure and exclude them from flying duties before they become a safety risk in emergency situations.

The creation of many different failure scenarios in simulation training can prevent a pilot from becoming caught in a flight situation for which he has never been trained before, avoiding the stress generated by having to deal with novel problems.
Simulation of multiple failures in training situations ideally prepares pilots for hand-flying their aircraft in actual failure situations, despite high automation in daily operations.

variant.question: Anxiety can affect: - Judgment - Attention - Memory - Concentration

options.text: 1 only

variant.question: Cognitive evaluation which leads to stress is based on..

options.text: the evaluation of the situation and the evaluation of capabilities to cope with it.
the evaluation of the capabilities of the individual and the time available.
the capabilities of the individual and the solutions provided by the environment.
the evaluation of the situation and the state of fatigue of the individual.

variant.question: What are the three phases of General Adaptation Syndrome?

options.text: Alarm, resistance, exhaustion.
Alert, resistance, exhaustion.
Alert, resistance, performance.
Alarm, resistance, performance.

variant.question: What are the three phases of General Adaptation Syndrome ?

options.text: Alarm, resistance, exhaustion.
Alert, resistance, exhaustion
Alarm, resistance, performance,
Alert, resistance, performance.

variant.question:
Any stimulus that causes stress is referred to as a stressor
In the cockpit, an example of an environmental stressor is

options.text: engine noise.
financial worries.
work overload.
lack of sleep.

variant.question: Cognitive coping is associated with:

options.text: ignoring or rationalising the stress factor.
a deliberate removal of the stressor.
taking medicine to relieve the effects of stress.
eliminating the source of the stressor.

variant.question:
Situations particularly vulnerable to reversion to an earlier behaviour pattern are
1) when concentration on a particular task is relaxed.
2) when situations are characterised by medium workload.
3) when situations are characterised by stress.

Too high workload can cause several problems
Which problem has been a contributing factor in many accidents?

options.text: Loss of situational awareness.
Poor visual scanning for other aeroplanes.
Hurry up errors.
Incapacitation.

variant.question:
The cognitive effects of stress may include:
1) excessive haste.
2) an improvement in memory.
3) a complete block: action is impossible.
4) a risk of focusing on a particular aspect.
5) ease of decision-making.
6) an increase in the rate of mistakes.
The combination which brings together all correct statements is:
The "Break Point" is that point after which, if stress continues to rise,

options.text: Performance is degraded.
Performance is enhanced.
Performance peaks and remains at this level.
Performance is initially degraded and is then enhanced.

variant.question: High levels of stress may cause regression, which can lead to

options.text: correct actions being forgotten and substituted for incorrect procedures.
an improvement in the efficient use of mental capacity and overall performance.
experimentation and the trying out of new ideas.
a deterioration in performance, though an improved awareness of external factors.

variant.question: The initial stress response is characterised by the following symptoms:

options.text: Faster and deeper inhalation, dry mouth, dilated pupils
Increased rate and depth of breathing, stabbing pain around the heart.
Accelerated pulse rate, hypoxia.
Increased sweat production, heartburn, gastric and duodenal ulcers.

variant.question: Name the major drawback of Stress Exposure Training in aviation.

options.text: Totally unexpected situations cannot be created.
It is cost-intensive and uses up a lot of time.
It does not focus on a specific problem which is trained in-depth.
Failure to complete the task may cause additional fear in pilots.

variant.question: Name the major drawback of Stress Exposure Training in aviation.

options.text: Totally unexpected situations cannot be generated.
It is cost-intensive and uses up a lot of time.
It does not focus on a specific problem which is trained in-depth.

variant.question:
Stress is a reaction in order to adapt to a specific situation
This reaction

options.text: may include various psychological and physiological elements which one can learn to manage.
is always linked to excessive fear.
is purely physiological and automatic.
can only be controlled by medical treatment.

variant.question: The first cockpit tool that tends to suffer as a result of stress

options.text: Cockpit communications
Cockpit entity
Cockpit cohesion
Cockpit synergy

variant.question: Which of the following is an example of poor performance due to human overload?

options.text: Forgetting to monitor the fuel level during an emergency situation with high workload.
A missed radio call on a regularly flown route in perfect weather during a low-workload period of flight.
Damaging the aircraft in a forced landing following a low-altitude double engine failure.
A bad landing on a VFR day.

1) alarm.
2) alert phase.
3) resistance phase.
4) exhaustion phase.

An overstressed pilot may show the following symptoms: - Mental blocks, confusion and channelized attention - Resignation, frustration, rage - Deterioration in motor coordination - High pitch voice and fast speaking

options.text: 1, 2, 3 and 4 are correct.
1 and 2 are correct, 3 and 4 are false.
1, 2 and 3 are correct, 4 is false.

variant.question: What is the main adverse effect of expectations in the perception mechanism?

options.text: Expectations often guide the focus of attention towards a particular aspect, while possible alternates are neglected.

They always lead to routine errors.
The unconscious mechanism of attention leads to focus on all relevant information.

options.text: Cognitive stress.
organisational stress.

variant.question: What triggers stress in humans?

options.text: The subjective interpretation an individual gives to a situation experienced.
Always the awareness of an emotion and a physiological activation (e.g. rapid heart rate).
Objective stimulation from the environment regardless of subjective perceptions.
Only strong excitations of the sensory organs: a flash of light, noise, the smell of smoke.

variant.question: An increase in workload usually leads to

options.text: a shorter and less frequent exchange of information.
a longer and less frequent exchange of information.
a longer and more frequent exchange of information.
a shorter and more frequent exchange of information.

variant.question: What does the "end deterioration effect" (Home-itis) mean?

options.text: The tendency to sudden, imperceptible errors shortly before the end of a flight.
The breakdown of crew coordination due to interpersonal tensions between captain and co-pilot.
The potential risk of loosing orientation after flying in clouds.
The result of a poor preflight planning.
